Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on advancing integrative volcanology with community experiments: Albuquerque, NM, November 28-30, 2018
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a community workshop in November 2018 to synthesize multidisciplinary perspectives on how community projects can advance integrative volcanology. One of the key challenges identified by recent community reports on research in volcanic systems is enhancing community organization to overcome observational and disciplinary limitations. The proposed workshop would help foster community organization, encourage early career scientists to take an active role in guiding the field, and set the stage for ambitious and innovative near-future projects.Community projects with open data and a framework for coordinating interdisciplinary research on volcanic systems would benefit training and opportunities for the next generation of volcano scientists and maximize outcomes from investment in volcanology beyond what is possible with individual investigator or small group projects. The overarching goal is to advance process-based understanding of the life cycles of volcanic systems that are important hazards to life and infrastructure as well as longterm drivers of geological processes central geothermal energy and concentration of economically valuable elements and minerals.

The complex geophysical and geochemical processes and geological history underlying volcanic systems demands extensive observational resources and interdisciplinary engagement to develop models of volcanic processes. Much progress has been made to date primarily using research projects driven by individual investigators or small groups who perform all parts of the project (collection of observation, analysis, interpretation) and may eventually make their data openly available after project completion. There is growing recognition that continued advances could benefit greatly from pooling resources to collect diverse cutting-edge observations, expansion of open-access data and data products, and increasing coordination among observational and theoretical approaches. The proposed workshop will provide an opportunity for well-motivated and focused discussions leading to recommendations for how community volcano experiments could be an increasingly useful mode of operation in the near future. Workshop goals include identifying the key problems suited to community experiments, elements of potential experiment designs and locations, and key aspects of integrative research frameworks to maximize the benefit of community experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Community projects that solicit broad participation and generate open-access data sets have seen increasing use among the geoscience community in recent years because continued advances in fundamental geoscience problems demand substantial and coordinated investment in new observational scales or approaches. Open access data, as exemplified by the NSF EarthScope program, has facilitated shared community resources, broad data usage, and comparison between techniques and models that would otherwise be impossible. Currently, the lack of community-scale open-access projects with an interdisciplinary volcanology perspective provides a limited base of experience upon which researchers can advocate for and propose new large initiatives. The workshop funded by this grant gathered members of the volcanology community to identify the most pressing questions that are best addressed through community projects and explore the merits of different potential models for community projects. Discussion and synthesis of recommendations for community projects spanned strategies for coordinated multidisciplinary observations, integrative modeling approaches, effective incorporation of education and training opportunities, and development of a community framework to foster participation in integrative research. The resulting workshop report was drafted by the organizing committee using extensive notes form discussion group session. A draft was made available for open comments from workshop participants and the broader volcanology community, and then it was revised accordingly before final distribution and online posting. The workshop report should be useful to motivate and guide the development of future community volcano projects that successfully address key challenges in volcanology and maximize their positive impact.
